@metadata.goal: The student can partition shapes into equal parts

steps.dialogue: Compare these two bars. Which one shows thirds correctly? Look for 3 equal parts, not just 3 parts.

step.dialogue: Not quite. Look for the bar where all three parts are the same size.

events.name: highlight_smallest_largest
events.description: The smallest and largest sections of the top bar pulse to show size differences

events.name: glow_equal_parts
events.description: All three sections of the bottom bar glow together to show they are equal

step.dialogue: [event:highlight_smallest_largest][event:glow_equal_parts]Let's think about this together. For thirds, we need 3 equal parts. Check if each part in your selected bar is exactly the same size.

events.name: measure_sections_unequal
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines highlighting size differences between sections in the top bar

events.name: measure_sections_equal
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines confirming all sections in the bottom bar are equal width

step.dialogue: [event:measure_sections_unequal][event:measure_sections_equal]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. Thirds means 3 equal parts. The top bar has 3 parts, but they're different sizes. The bottom bar has 3 parts that are all the same size. That's how thirds work - all three parts need to be equal.

on_correct.dialogue: You found the bar with 3 equal parts.
